results.abstract: Former Pres George Bush this week took off on ceremonial flight from Houston Intercontinental Airport and returned 50 minutes later to the newly renamed George Bush International Airport (Chronicle column) (S)
results.snippet: GEORGE BUSH has certainly been taking to the skies lately. In March, he parachuted down to the Arizona desert 50 years after having bailed out of a bomber in the Pacific.    On Wednesday, the former President took off on a sunset flight from Houston...
results.lead_paragraph: GEORGE BUSH has certainly been taking to the skies lately. In March, he parachuted down to the Arizona desert 50 years after having bailed out of a bomber in the Pacific. On Wednesday, the former President took off on a sunset flight from Houston Intercontinental Airport and returned 50 minutes later to the newly renamed George Bush Intercontinental Airport.

results.abstract: City College of New York marks its 150th anniversary on May 7; 9,620 students at Harlem campus are aware, sometimes frustratingly so, of college's rich tradition; while college is now very different from white, largely Jewish institution of decades past, with far more immigrants and more students who require remedial courses, they say it continues to meet its historic mission of transforming New York City's poor and working class and sending them off as doctors, engineers and social workers; photos (M)

headline.kicker: At City College, Rich Tradition Meets Change
headline.main: Proletarian Harvard Turns 150, Its Mission Expanding

results.snippet: City College alumni in tuxedos and evening gowns packed the ballroom of Manhattan's Sheraton Hotel last month to show their affection for a school that turned 150 years old yesterday. These sons and daughters of the working class paid $500 a plate...
results.lead_paragraph: City College alumni in tuxedos and evening gowns packed the ballroom of Manhattan's Sheraton Hotel last month to show their affection for a school that turned 150 years old yesterday. These sons and daughters of the working class paid $500 a plate for the pleasure, more than their entire college educations had cost them (books and subway tokens included). The evening was a tribute to the astonishing achievement of a college that has become legendary as a proletarian Harvard. At one table sat five of the college's eight Nobel Prize winners, and at other tables were real estate magnates, Wall Street financiers, mayors, judges and newspaper editors. There was a film that showed off such graduates as Felix Frankfurter, Upton Sinclair, Bernard Malamud and Ira Gershwin. And the featured speaker was Gen. Colin L. Powell, Class of 1958, the hero of the Persian Gulf War whose military career was spawned in the college's early-morning R.O.T.C. drills.

results.abstract: Brief review by Janet Maslin of film The Evening Star, which has been released on videocassette (S)
results.snippet: The Evening Star  1996. Paramount. $100.71. Laser disk, $44.98. 129 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.      A follow-up to ''Terms of Endearment'' finds little to do but wallow in the grandmotherly routine of Aurora Greenway (Shirley MacLaine)....
results.lead_paragraph: The Evening Star 1996. Paramount. $100.71. Laser disk, $44.98. 129 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. A follow-up to ''Terms of Endearment'' finds little to do but wallow in the grandmotherly routine of Aurora Greenway (Shirley MacLaine). Aurora tends to her following of friends and admirers and the three adult children of the deceased Emma (Debra Winger in the first film). Such is Aurora's appeal that she attracts a young therapist (Bill Pullman) and inspires encomiums from the former astronaut Garrett Breedlove (Jack Nicholson), who resurfaces in a sequel that is ''wayward and needless'' (Maslin).

results.abstract: Second Lieut Kelly Flinn, graduate of Air Force Academy and first woman to become B-52 bomber pilot, is about to be court-martialed on charges that arose from her love affair with civilian; charges including adultery and insubordination have left her facing not only dismissal but prison sentence of up to nine and half years, and has left Air Force officials wishing that it had never come to this; Sen Slade Gorton has urged Air Force Sec Sheila Widnall to dismiss charges, and Pentagon has ordered sweeping review on personal relationships in all services; photo (M)

headline.main: From a Love Affair to a Court-Martial

results.snippet: In 1995, the Air Force filmed a promotional television story on an officer who was about to make Air Force history: the first woman to become a B-52 bomber pilot.    There is Second Lieut. Kelly Flinn peering under the wing of the nuclear-armed...
results.lead_paragraph: In 1995, the Air Force filmed a promotional television story on an officer who was about to make Air Force history: the first woman to become a B-52 bomber pilot. There is Second Lieut. Kelly Flinn peering under the wing of the nuclear-armed plane, the wind sweeping through her closely cropped blond hair, Kelly Flinn sitting in a simulated B-52 seat, inspecting the controls. Her future, the report said, ''may one day include becoming squadron commander and a shuttle astronaut.''

results.abstract: International crew of astronauts aboard space shuttle Atlantis takes off on planned nine-day mission to make repairs to aging Russian space station Mir; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Takes Off to Fortify the Mir Station

results.snippet: An international crew of astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis took off today on a planned nine-day mission for a critical visit to the aging Russian space station Mir.    Lifting off in the dark before dawn, the shuttle climbed to an orbit...
results.lead_paragraph: An international crew of astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis took off today on a planned nine-day mission for a critical visit to the aging Russian space station Mir. Lifting off in the dark before dawn, the shuttle climbed to an orbit 184 miles above Earth, where it began maneuvering toward a rendezvous with the Mir on Friday night over Russia. That will be none too soon for the three Mir astronauts, including an American physician.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   3-7    Mobutu Surrenders Power And Then Flees Into Exile   President Mobutu Sese Seko yielded power after Army leaders in Zaire told him they would not fight rebel forces led by Laurent Kabila and urged him to leave the country. Mr....
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-7 Mobutu Surrenders Power And Then Flees Into Exile President Mobutu Sese Seko yielded power after Army leaders in Zaire told him they would not fight rebel forces led by Laurent Kabila and urged him to leave the country. Mr. Mobutu took his family to his hometown and then, reportedly, on to Morocco. His Information Minister said that Mr. Mobutu remained President but had ''ceased to intervene'' in the affairs of state. 1 Some people played golf as Kinshasa awaited the arrival of Zaire's rebel army with surprising nonchalance. 6 Blair Opens Door to Sinn Fein Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said he would allow British officials to resume contact with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Blair, visiting Belfast, said that renewing official contact depended on an absence of I.R.A. violence, although he did not specifically call for a cease-fire. Sinn Fein's No. 2 official, Martin McGuinness, said his party would accept Mr. Blair's offer. 1 De Klerk Will Shun Inquiry Former President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa ended his National Party's cooperation with the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, hobbling its effort to heal deep divisions over past atrocities. Panel members, particularly Archbishop Desmond Tutu. had criticized Mr. de Klerk's recent testimony as lacking credibility. 3 Mexican Prosecutor Arrested Authorities in Spain have arrested Pablo Chapa Bezanilla, Mexico's former top prosecutor. Mr. Chapa disappeared after being charged with rigging evidence in a murder case involving Mexico's political establishment. He was accused of trying to frame Raul Salinas, the brother of Mexico's former President, by planting bones on his ranch. 4 Stalemate in Middle East Dennis Ross ended a nine-day visit to the Middle East, where he is President Clinton's special envoy, with no progress to report in talks between Israel and the Palestinians. Israeli planes attacked suspected bases of the Hezbollah in southern Lebanon, avenging the killing of three Israeli soldiers there. 5 Riots in Port-au-Prince Mobs burned cars and exchanged gunfire with police officers in the streets of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, as student demonstrations flared into a day of general rioting. Businesses closed, and downtown residents fled as the rioters hurled rocks. Five people were seriously injured. The rioting was triggered by a teachers' strike. (AP) No Visas for Hong Kong Visits In a move to maintain Hong Kong as a global business and tourism hub, China has announced that foreigners who now travel to the territory without visas may continue to do so after July 1, when the colony reverts to Chinese rule. The Foreign Ministry said Hong Kong's postcolonial Government would decide on which countries' nationals would have the right to enter without visas. They would still be required to travel to other parts of China. (AP) NATIONAL 8-11 House Committee Passes Outline of the Budget Plan The House Budget Committee approved a resolution that will serve as a guide for future action on tax cuts and spending under the balanced-budget agreement. Republican leaders said they expected both the House and the Senate would give final approval by the end of next week. 9 Apology for Syphilis Study President Clinton apologized to the survivors and to relatives of 399 black men whose syphilis was left untreated for decades as part of a Federal study. 10 Abortion Vote May Change Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said he might reverse his stand and vote for a ban on what abortion opponents call ''partial-birth abortion.'' If he did, the Senate would be more likely to override an expected veto by President Clinton of the ban. 11 No Delay for Pilot's Trial The judge in the court-martial of the nation's first female B-52 pilot denied a defense request to delay her trial on adultery and other charges for two weeks. The court-martial of First Lieut. Kelly Flinn is expected to start on Tuesday. 10 Governor's Trial Starts A Federal prosecutor told jurors on the opening day of the fraud trial of Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona that Mr. Symington tried to save his crumbling real estate business through a web of deceit. A defense lawyer said his client had taken risks but never lied. 8 Shuttle Docks With Mir The space shuttle Atlantis docked with the Russian orbiting station Mir, carrying an astronaut who will join the Russian crew and equipment needed to insure that they have breathable air. 10 Explosion for Plane Safety Aviation experts will detonate four small explosions in a Boeing 747 to test reinforced cargo holds and baggage containers. The test will take place in England on Saturday. 8 NEW YORK/REGION 21-25 Fugitive Author Arrested After Motel Suicide Threat A romance novelist who fled from New York after being convicted of stealing a Picasso sketch and other valuables in 1995, was arrested at a California motel. The writer, Barbara Joslyn, stabbed herself in the chest after police officers came to her room to apprehend her. 21 Doctor to Begin Jail Term Dr. Gerald Einaugler, who delayed having a nursing home patient hospitalized after he made a potentially fatal treatment mistake, is about to go to jail, after four years of court battles. He was convicted of criminal negligence and violation of state health laws, and was sentenced to a year of weekends at Rikers Island, although state medical officials declined to discipline him. 23 Danish Mother Is Cleared Charges were dismissed against a Danish tourist who was arrested for leaving her baby in a stroller outside a Manhattan restaurant where she was eating. But charges against the father, who is a New Yorker, remain. The woman had said that Danes commonly leave toddlers on the sidewalk while shopping or eating. 23 Bruno Shifts Rent Stance Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, said he could support allowing immediate family members to inherit rent regulated apartments for one generation. 22 Legislature Is Overturned The Rockland County Legislature is unconstitutional, a Federal judge declared. By dividing representation by towns, voters do not have comparable voting power, he ruled. 24 SPORTS 26-31 Short-Handed Knicks Lose The Knicks lost last night's playoff game to the Miami Heat, 95-90, after a Federal judge upheld the suspensions of Patrick Ewing, Allan Houston and three teammates. The teams will meet in Miami for a decisive seventh game on Sunday, when Ewing and Houston will return but John Starks and Larry Johnson will be suspended. 1 BUSINESS DAY 32-45 Dow Drops 138 Points The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 138.88 points, or 1.89 percent. The decline, to 7,194.67, was part of a retreat lead by a selloff of computer and technology stocks and declines in drug, banking, soft drink and household product stocks. 33 Slow Growth in Housing The number of single-family houses being built rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month. Some economists said it was an indication that economic growth was moderating. Construction of apartment buildings led to an overall increase in housing starts of 2.6 percent. 34 Business Digest 32 ARTS 13-17, 20 OBITUARIES 12 James M. Fox The former head of the New York office of the F.B.I., who helped jail John Gotti and the men who bombed the World Trade Center, was 59. 12 Saadallah Wannous One of the Arab world's leading playwrights was 56. 12 EDITORIAL 18-19 Editorials: An African tyrant departs, violations of the heart, equity for New Jersey's schools. Columns: Russell Baker, Maureen Dowd. Bridge 17 Crossword 16 Weather 25

results.abstract: Philanthropist Eugene M Lang, who in 1981 promised 61 sixth graders in Harlem that if they graduated from high school, he would make sure they got chance to attend college by providing mentors and scholarships, extends his offer to include children of original students; photo (M)

headline.main: Gift of an Education For the 2d Generation

results.snippet: In 1981, Eugene M. Lang surprised 61 fidgety sixth graders in a Harlem auditorium with the promise that if they graduated from high school, he would make sure they got the chance to attend college. And he did, providing mentors and scholarships that...
results.lead_paragraph: In 1981, Eugene M. Lang surprised 61 fidgety sixth graders in a Harlem auditorium with the promise that if they graduated from high school, he would make sure they got the chance to attend college. And he did, providing mentors and scholarships that kept most of them in school and on a path to greater things. Now Mr. Lang, a multimillionaire industrialist who later encouraged similar efforts through his I Have a Dream Foundation in cities across America, wants to help the next generation. Speaking before a hushed crowd of those original students and their families yesterday on the 16th anniversary of his original gift, Mr. Lang announced that he would extend his scholarship fund to include the children of those he first took under his wing.

results.abstract: American and Russian astronauts carrying out resupply mission for Russia's ailing Mir space station participate in live call-in show on cable network; avoid questions from viewers about having sex in space (S)
results.snippet: Ten American and Russian astronauts carrying out a resupply mission for Russia's ailing Mir station were participating in a live call-in show on the C-SPAN cable network today, when Caller No. 4 brought up NASA's No. 1 taboo:    ''I was just...
results.lead_paragraph: Ten American and Russian astronauts carrying out a resupply mission for Russia's ailing Mir station were participating in a live call-in show on the C-SPAN cable network today, when Caller No. 4 brought up NASA's No. 1 taboo: ''I was just wondering, has anybody ever thought about having sex in space?'' a Chico, Calif., man asked. ''Raising a family in space?'' Yes, tell us about the rules on that, the C-SPAN interviewer interjected.

results.abstract: American astronaut Dr C Michael Foale, recent arrival on Russian space station Mir, comments on stay (S)

headline.main: New Astronaut on Mir Likes the Pace

results.snippet: The newest resident of the Russian space station Mir is slipping easily into its routine, finding the food better than expected and the pace slow and easy.    ''The shuttle guys are having to work to a time line that's compressed,'' Dr. C. Michael...
results.lead_paragraph: The newest resident of the Russian space station Mir is slipping easily into its routine, finding the food better than expected and the pace slow and easy. ''The shuttle guys are having to work to a time line that's compressed,'' Dr. C. Michael Foale, an American astronaut, said today on the fourth day of his stay aboard the Mir. ''They have to get back on Earth.

results.abstract: Interview with Martin Weissman, who has long made his Pensacola, Fla, bar, Trader Jon's, shrine to Blue Angels, Navy's precision flying squadron, and other military aviators; bar has served as home for generations of pilots; photo (M)

headline.main: Honorary Avaiator Tends Blue Angels Shrine

results.snippet: In the cool of the morning, before even the first of the daytime drinkers enters his ramshackle bar on Palafox Street, it is just Martin Weissman and the angels.    The angels, Blue Angels, peer down from hundreds of photographs tacked to the walls,...
results.lead_paragraph: In the cool of the morning, before even the first of the daytime drinkers enters his ramshackle bar on Palafox Street, it is just Martin Weissman and the angels. The angels, Blue Angels, peer down from hundreds of photographs tacked to the walls, all clean-cut, confident, smiling young men in flight suits, men who pose beside their lovely, dangerous planes. The old bar is a shrine to all aviators, but especially the Angels, the Navy's precision flying squadron, based here, that has thrilled and terrified air-show audiences for 50 years.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-13    Reformist Hand Is Visible In Russian Budget Plan  Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin urged Parliament to slash spending on the military and state-subsidized industries to make up for a gaping revenue shortfall in this year's...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Reformist Hand Is Visible In Russian Budget Plan Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin urged Parliament to slash spending on the military and state-subsidized industries to make up for a gaping revenue shortfall in this year's budget. His plan explicitly rejected printing more money and reflected the influence of reformers in President Boris Yeltsin's cabinet. A1 Brazil Favors Second Terms Brazil's Senate voted overwhelmingly in favor of a constitutional amendment that would allow the president, state governors and mayors to run for second terms. The amendment must pass a final Senate vote, set for early June. The amendment was the first bill presented by President Fernando Henrique Cardoso after he was elected to a first term three years ago. A3

results.abstract: Astronaut Jerry M Linenger expects to be taking slow, clumsy baby steps, just like his toddler son, when he returns to Earth's gravity after four months on Russian space station Mir (S)

headline.main: Astronaut Expects To Take Baby Steps

results.snippet: Dr. Jerry M. Linenger expects to be taking slow, clumsy baby steps -- just like his 18-month-old son, John -- when he returns to Earth this weekend after four months on the Russian space station Mir.    Adjusting to weightlessness was ''as rapid as...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jerry M. Linenger expects to be taking slow, clumsy baby steps -- just like his 18-month-old son, John -- when he returns to Earth this weekend after four months on the Russian space station Mir. Adjusting to weightlessness was ''as rapid as that of a child learning how to walk, learning how to talk,'' said Dr. Linenger, 42, a sports medicine specialist who chronicled his experiences on the Mir in letters to John, his first-born. ''I think when I land on Earth I'm going to be clumsy again and have to go through that process again a little bit.''

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12    Russian Military Leaders Are Dismissed by Yeltsin  President Boris N. Yeltsin scathingly dismissed Russia's two top military leaders, criticizing their resistance to budget cuts. The head of Russia's long-range nuclear...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Russian Military Leaders Are Dismissed by Yeltsin President Boris N. Yeltsin scathingly dismissed Russia's two top military leaders, criticizing their resistance to budget cuts. The head of Russia's long-range nuclear arsenal was named acting Defense Minister, replacing Igor N. Rodionov, whose dismissal was televised as a warning to other officials. A1 Surprise Contender in Iran To the surprise of the ruling mullahs in Iran, Mohammed Khatami has drawn huge crowds and emerged as a serious liberal contender in the presidential election today. No real competition had been expected for Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, the Speaker of the Parliament and the mullahs' choice. Iran's president has limited powers compared with the unelected ''supreme leader,'' Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. A1 Albright Announces Sanctions Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced sanctions against two Chinese companies and a handful of Chinese executives, saying they had knowingly helped Iran make chemical weapons. She said there was no evidence that the Chinese Government had been involved in the companies' efforts to export chemicals and equipment. A1 NATO to Expand Role in Bosnia NATO forces in Bosnia will add non-military tasks to their duties, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said. The change is part of an effort to renew the momentum of the peace accords signed in Dayton, Ohio, eighteen months ago. Ms. Albright is to travel to Bosnia next week. A6 Swiss Reject U.S. Criticism Swiss Foreign Minister Flavio Cotti rejected as ''unsupported'' and ''one-sided'' the accusations made in a United States Government report that Switzerland had undermined its vaunted neutrality and prolonged World War II by acting as a banker to Nazi Germany. Mr. Cotti conceded that mistakes had been made but said that his country's national survival had been at stake. A7 Israel Plans Arab Housing The Israeli Interior Ministry said it had approved construction of 3,400 homes in an Arab village next to a hill in Jerusalem where work on a new Jewish neighborhood has seriously frustrated Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. The Government had pledged to approve Arab housing when it authorized construction of the Jewish settlement, known as Har Homa. Palestinian officials dismissed the Israeli announcement as propaganda. A10 Sainthood for Jewish-Born Nun Pope John Paul II formally approved sainthood for Edith Stein, a Jewish-born nun killed in a Holocaust gas chamber. No date for the canonization ceremony, which would make her a Roman Catholic saint, was announced. The nun's beatification in 1987 drew criticism from some Jews, who said the Nazis had killed her because of her Jewish heritage, not because of her Catholicism. (AP) NATIONAL A14-24 Embattled Air Force Pilot Accepts General Discharge The country's first female B-52 pilot, First Lieut. Kelly Flinn, will accept a general discharge from the Air Force rather than face a court-martial for adultery, lying and other charges that could have sent her to prison for up to nine and a half years. Air Force officials said a general discharge meant that Lieutenant Flinn would almost certainly not be allowed to fly in the Air Force Reserves and would be required to pay back about $20,000 of the cost of her Air Force Academy education. A1 McVeigh's Defense Begins The lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh opened their defense by raising the possibility that someone else had been the bomber in the attack on the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and had been killed in the blast. Oklahoma's medical examiner testified that that he had never been able to link a severed leg found at the scene to a body. A1 Spending Plans Rejected The Senate voted down the last major amendment to the budget resolution, a proposal to spent more money on Federal highway projects, as it moved toward a Congressional commitment to balance the Federal budget by 2002. A measure to set aside $5 billion to rebuild crumbling schools was also defeated. A21 Astronaut Set for Return Jerry M. Linenger expects to walk off Atlantis when he returns to Earth on Saturday after four months on Mir. NASA wants astronauts to be carried off the shuttle after long stretches in space because that makes scientific tests easier to carry out. But only one of Dr. Linenger's three predecessors aboard the Mir was carried from Atlantis. A23 Times Lists Staff Changes Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor of The New York Times, announced the appointments of a managing editor and two deputy managing editors. Bill Keller, 48, the foreign editor and a Pulitzer Prize winner, will become managing editor at the end of September, succeeding Gene Roberts, who will end his leave from the University of Maryland and return to teaching journalism there. The deputy managing editor for news will be Gerald M. Boyd, 46, and the deputy for operations will be John M. Geddes, 45. C31 Laurels for Longevity Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, who, at age 94, is already the oldest person ever to serve as a member of Congress, will become the longest-serving Senator in the chamber's history on Sunday. Senator Thurmond says he feels like a ''million dollars'' but would vote for term limits without compunction. A22 Cigars Appealing to the Young More than one-quarter of all boys and girls 14 to 19 years old smoked at least one cigar last year, a Federal study found. The findings astonished public health advocates, who immediately called for Federal warning labels on cigars. A24 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Mobsters' Guards Accused Of Making Jail Cushy Federal officials announced the arrest of 20 people in a sting operation into corruption among guards at a new Federal jail in Brooklyn. The authorities said corrupt guards let top mobsters turn the jail into a social club, where they plotted crimes and sipped vodka and wine. A1 Teacher Accused of Sex Abuse A 41-year-old Brooklyn music teacher, Michael Williams, was charged with sexually abusing a 13-year-old female student in his locked classroom last month. It was the second case in a week in which officials said administrators in a New York City public school had failed to respond promptly in a case involving charges of sexual abuse of a student. The earlier case occurred in Queens. B1 Pataki Yields to Indians Governor Pataki abandoned his effort to collect taxes on gasoline and cigarette sales on Indian reservations. The move was criticized by owners of small businesses operating outside reservations, who have long complained that selling tax-free goods gaves Indian competitors an unfair advantage. But Indian leaders said the move affirmed the tribes' status as sovereign peoples. B1 Harassment Suit Is Filed The Federal Government filed a sexual harassment suit against Sidney Frank Importing and All States Promotions, a liquor importer and a marketing firm, both based in New Rochelle, N.Y., charging that top executives kissed, fondled and made improper advances to more than 100 women employees. A spokesman for the companies denied the charges. B6 Slain Officer Is Buried A funeral was held in West Babylon for Officer Anthony Sanchez, the first police officer killed on the job this year. His wife, Elizabeth, speaking of their 7-year-old son, said, ''John says farewell to the daddy taken from him too soon, who gave him so much love.'' B3 BUSINESS DAY D1-16 Dispute Over Prenatal Test A company headed by Dr. Mark Bogart, Biomedical Patent Management, is demanding that labs across the country pay large royalties when they conduct a prenatal test he says is based on work he patented in 1986. Some labs said they might have to stop doing the test. A1 Low-End Wages on the Rise Wages at the low end of the economic scale have spurted up in the last 18 months. D1 Business Digest D1 SPORTS B7-15 WEEKEND C1-31 Elbow Room for Chinese Art The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its expanded galleries for Chinese art. C1 OBITUARIES A25 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Russia's budget crunch, the discharge of Kelly Flinn, Bob Dole is not a bank, shortchanging students at Hostos. Columns: Anthony Lewis, A. M. Rosenthal. Chronicle D18 Crossword C30 Weather B6

results.abstract: Editorial Notebook by Philip Taubman on rattletrap condition of Soviet space station Mir, which NASA has played down, while sending up another astronaut, Michael Foale; recalls shortcomings of Soviet Union's vaunted technology even in earlier years, and suggests that risk of living aboard Mir now may be akin to moving into Texas trailer park minutes before tornado hits
results.snippet: Every time I hear of some new breakdown aboard Russia's Mir space station, I think of my visit some years ago to the Space Research Institute in Moscow. The institute was home to some of the world's most advanced scientific work, and had just...
results.lead_paragraph: Every time I hear of some new breakdown aboard Russia's Mir space station, I think of my visit some years ago to the Space Research Institute in Moscow. The institute was home to some of the world's most advanced scientific work, and had just choreographed a rendezvous in distant space for one of its spacecraft and Halley's comet. Surely this was one Soviet organization that had eliminated the backward technology so evident in more pedestrian fields like consumer electronics. Then I saw the cashier at the institute cafeteria. She was calculating my lunch tab on an abacus. Michael Foale, the latest American astronaut to take up residence aboard Mir, may not want to look too closely at his quarters. Several years of firsthand experience with Soviet technology tell me the station, now in its 11th year in orbit, is a space jalopy.

results.abstract: Larry Rohter reports on making of movie From the Earth to the Moon, project of actor Tom Hanks; Hanks, who became interested in space travel when he was in movie Apollo 13, is not acting this time, but is wearing hat of executive producer and is also serving as a director and screenwriter; From the Earth to the Moon is to be 13-part dramatic anthology that will appear on HBO next spring; National Aeronautics and Space Administration is providing a few of locations and some of props for anthology; NASA officials consulted by Hanks say he and his team are accurately capturing atmosphere of the Apollo era; photos (L)

headline.main: On a Mission to Dramatize the Space Race

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: FROM THE EARTH TO THE MOON (TV PROGRAM)

results.snippet: AS ANY CONSCIENTIOUS ACTOR  would, Tom Hanks did a lot of research after he was cast as the astronaut James Lovell in Ron Howard's movie ''Apollo 13.'' He read book after book, talked with astronauts and their families, visited Cape Canaveral and...
results.lead_paragraph: AS ANY CONSCIENTIOUS ACTOR would, Tom Hanks did a lot of research after he was cast as the astronaut James Lovell in Ron Howard's movie ''Apollo 13.'' He read book after book, talked with astronauts and their families, visited Cape Canaveral and spent time with ground-control technicians. Yet when he was finished, he felt that he had barely scratched the surface, and he hungered to do more. Now, almost four years later, Mr. Hanks is getting a second crack at the subject he regards as perhaps the ''most romantic and inspiring'' of the modern age: man's quest to reach and explore the moon. This time, he is not appearing on screen but is wearing the hat of executive producer and is also serving as a director and a screenwriter. Working with the same production team that made ''Apollo 13,'' he has spent months writing and revising scripts, lining up actors, directors and writers and obtaining the substantial financial backing required to make ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' a 13-part dramatic anthology that will appear on HBO next spring.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-11    Prime Minister of France Says He Will Resign  Alain Juppe said he would resign as Prime Minister of France even if the conservative coalition he leads wins in the second round of voting on Sunday. Mr. Juppe was widely seen...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Prime Minister of France Says He Will Resign Alain Juppe said he would resign as Prime Minister of France even if the conservative coalition he leads wins in the second round of voting on Sunday. Mr. Juppe was widely seen as the reason that the governing coalition received fewer votes than the assorted parties of the left. A1 Conservative parties across Europe winced at the outcome of the French elections. The center-right party of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany worried about elections in 1998. A9
